column78: "description": "In the battle between Light and Dark
column79:
engineers shape humanity’s fate

[Spoiler warning: Some plot assumptions and an important character’s story 
are discussed in detail]  

In a story where engineers are more central than Jedi or Sith
column80:
Rogue One 
breaks new ground for the franchise both in its characters but also in the 
ethical territory it covers.  Not to diminish the character arcs of Jyn 
Erso and Cassian Andor
column81:
but the core ethical arc of the film is one man’s 
decision to engineer the Death Star in such a way as to prevent its use for 
galactic domination. One could fairly retitle the movie to ‘Rogue One: an 
Engineering Ethics Story.’

Our scifipolicy.com review essay will address Rogue One as the engineering 
ethics case study it is. Properly understanding the ethical power of the 
engineers in Rogue One enriches our understanding of good and evil in the 
Star Wars universe and furthers our understanding of what engineering 
ethically truly means.   

Only part of the story: blowing the whistle on the Death Star

The movie begins with the Death Star program director
column82: Orson Krennic (Ben \r\nMendelsohn) finding and returning his escaped top scientist
column83: Galen Erso \r\n(Mads Mikkelsen). Despite all the resources of the Empire and its access to \r\nthe dark side
column84: the Death Star takes 15 more years to build
column85: requiring \r\nincredible effort and the capabilities of a top designer and scientist of \r\nGalen\u2019s caliber. The challenge of engineering was apparent to all
column86: as Grand \r\nMoff Tarkin notes years of challenges and delays. \u00a0It is important to note \r\nthat while the movie calls Galen a scientist
column87: he was leading a design \r\neffort and a team of engineers. To us
column88:
he clearly is an engineer[1].

The film also makes its engineering ethics explicit. Before the opening 
scene
column89: Galen Erso had escaped the Death Star project because of his moral \r\nobjections
column90: likely against the Empire as well as the concept of making such \r\na terrifying weapon at all. After Krennic captures him
column91: Galen later tells \r\nhis daughter Jyn that he had a choice: he could have continued abstaining
column92: \r\nand let someone else build the Death Star
column93: or he could dive deep into the \r\nproject
column95: and find a way to stop it. He chooses \r\nto dive deep
column96: and succeeds in building a subtle flaw in the Death Star \r\ndesign. Then 15 years later
column97: he sends a messenger to the Rebellion \r\ninforming them of the weapon\u2019s existence
column99:
its 
fatal flaw.

Galen’s reflection on engineering could have come straight out of real-life 
engineering discussions of the 1970s. As the historian Matthew Wisnioski 
captures in his book “Engineers for Change”
column100: many engineers were criticized \r\nduring the Vietnam War for their role in developing major weapons systems. \r\nIn the real world
column101: Galen could have become a conscientious objector and \r\nleft the project
column102: but oftentimes engineers can choose to stay engaged and \r\ntry to influence the project. In our world
column103:
some engineers did change 
fields and while some engineering societies sponsored large public debates 
about the role of technology in society. Engineering schools added ethics 
to their curriculum
column104:
but Wisnioski suggests that the changes were 
ultimately too narrow.

Unfortunately
column105: much of engineering ethics education has focused excessively \r\non whistleblowing
column106: and perhaps a limited view of Galen Erso\u2019s actions would \r\ncall what he did \u201cwhistle blowing
column107:
” as he alerted the rebels to the looming 
threat. We tend to agree with the engineer philosopher Samuel Florman who 
once wrote that “Whistle-blowing - to use a word that appears early and 
often in many discussions of engineering ethics - is a rare and extreme 
circumstance
column110:
but not deserving of the 
central role it has been given in studies of the field.” What Galen Erso 
does is not simply watch a system be built and then whistleblow; he 
actively shaped the design from its earliest stages considering its 
ultimate societal impacts.  These early design decisions are proactive 
rather than reactive
column111:
which is part of the broader engineering ethics 
lesson of Rogue One.

Shaping designs in pursuit of a more just world

Galen Erso
column112: as more than a conscientious whistleblower
column113: highlights what a \r\nbroader approach to engineering ethics can look like. Critically
column114: Galen \r\nmodified the Death Star design creating a critical flaw that could be used \r\nto destroy the Death Star. This weakness
column115: a path for a missile charge to \r\ntravel from the Death Star surface through an exhaust port to hit the \r\ncenter reactor
column116: was then exploited by the Rebels and
column118: Luke \r\nSkywalker in Episode IV. \u00a0Erso demonstrates that if one is imaginative \r\nenough
column119: there can be ways to change or modify a design so that it has a \r\ndifferent impact on society
column120: so that people can interact with the design in \r\na positive way
column121: or so that it can best contribute to a more just world.\r\n\r\nWhile Galen\u2019s change to the Death Star is an extreme case
column122: akin to \r\nmodifying a nuclear weapon design
column123:
engineers make many decisions that 
affect our everyday lives. Engineering and technology can critically define 
how people live and who has power. Philosopher of technology Langdon 
Winner’s article “Do Artifacts Have Politics?” argues that technology 
changes the world around them
column124: creating policies and politics that result \r\nfrom the inherent (at times destructive) characteristics of the technology. \r\nYet
column125:
it is not only the technology of advanced weapons that can shape our 
world. Social media and increased computer devices are affecting how humans 
think and how we act in a democratic society. An engineer must consider not 
only the function of a new system
column126: but how it will be used and the possible \r\nunintended consequences
column127:
just as Galen Orso did when designing the Death 
Star.  

A complementary point to Winner is to think through how we have to labor to 
maintain existing systems. Historians Andy Russell and Lee Vinsel have 
started a social movement called The Maintainers
column128:
which tries to call 
attention to the neglected role of maintenance in society. While the Star 
Wars universe has a lot of ships and cities that look like they’re in a 
state of dystopic disrepair
column129:
there are also many who scavenge (such as Rey) 
and make the most out of existing systems.. A robust discussion of 
engineering ethics should consider how we treat the people and 
technological systems that maintain the broader society.

The Force is not enough?

The above issues are all substantial parts of engineering ethics
column130:
but there 
is one more highly speculative thought about engineering ethics in Star 
Wars that I want to explore. Rogue One surprised me in how much it 
highlighted how the dark side seems to rely on technology. In my reading of 
the original films
column131: it always seemed to me that the Force was the most \r\npowerful source of change in the Galaxy
column132: and that the Empire relied on \r\ntechnology only incidentally. As Vader said in Episode IV
column133: the Death Star\u2019s \r\npower is \u201cinsignificant next to the power of the Force.\u201d The ultimate \r\nthreat was the Emperor
column134: and the two Death Stars and the Star Killer were \r\nsecondary
column135:
almost easily summoned into being just in time for the next 
movie plot.

In contrast to that
column136:
Rogue One shows that the engineering development of 
the Death Star took decades to complete and was a much more complex and 
vexing development than we knew. While its plans were briefly shown in the 
prequels
column137: the amount of work needed to make the Death Star a real \r\nengineering artifact required the focused attention over decades of \r\nKrennic
column138: Tarkin and Vader. In this film
column139: the Emperor\u2019s long term survival \r\nand goals for the dark side rely on the challenging
column141: and \r\nsometimes banal work of engineering and technology development. Despite the \r\nEmperor and Darth Vader\u2019s great power in the force
column142:
they needed technical 
superiority to establish permanent galactic control [2].  

One way of describing this is to say that the dark side is seeking a 
technological fix [3]. A technological fix
column143: as described by Daniel Sarewitz \r\n& Richard Nelson
column144: is a technological solution found to address a complex
column147: due to its \r\nassumed replicability and reliability. However
column148: problems in the real world \r\ncan simply be too complex
column149: defying any easy technological solution. \u00a0We \r\nnever really know how effective the Empire\u2019s technological fixes are
column151:
as the Rebels continue to destroy these mega-weapons before they 
are widely used.

But
column152: if the Death Stars are a technological \u2018fix\u2019
column153: then what is the problem \r\nthat it\u2019s trying to solve? Clearly they want to eliminate continued \r\nresistance to the Empire
column154: as well as the possibility of battle with future \r\nJedi or other light Side users. All technological factors being equal
column155: \r\nperhaps the battle between the light and dark side will always come to a \r\npartial d\u00e9tente
column156: as Yoda\u2019s battle with Palpatine showed. Without a \r\ntechnological edge
column157: there are individual victories that change the tide
column158:
but never fully wins the war.   The Death Star is the engineering artifact 
intended by the Emperor to tip the balance between the light and the dark. 
 

Interestingly
column159: the dark side users abide by the \u2018Rule of Two\u2019
column160: where there \r\nis only supposed to be a Sith master and a Sith apprentice
column161:
of which the 
latter is expected to take over from the master. This Rule of Two exists 
because multiple dark side users cannot be trusted: each will betray the 
others until they are in succession to eventually lead. Given the Rule of 
Two
column162: there can never be an army of multiple Sith that fight
column163: which means \r\nthey need accessories to help promote their goals. Perhaps in this way
column164:
the 
real problem that the the Death Star hopes to fix is one of trust: it lets 
the Sith maintain power over others without needing to involve and 
ultimately trust another Sith.

As mentioned
column165:
this discussion also changes the interpretation of Luke 
Skywalker’s victory against the Death Star in Episode IV. It’s not simply a 
case of using the Force to beat a technologically superior foe.  While the 
light side of the Force (and an assist from Han Solo) was needed
column166:
so too 
was the ethical engineer who built in a design flaw into the Death Star. 
The entire fight scene can now be scene as a battle of light and dark with 
engineers shaping the terms of engagement.  

Conclusion:

Rogue One’s core story arc is about an engineer influencing a technological 
system that will transform the political order of the galaxy. Ultimately
column167: \r\nGalen Erso engineers the system from the bottom up to have a critical flaw \r\nto ensure that this weapon of destruction could also
column169:
be destroyed. 
 This character reminds us all that engineers can and must insert ethics 
into the heart of their work.  Galen Erso’s ethical objections amount not 
just to whistle-blowing
column171: but limited part of \r\nengineering ethics. The movie demonstrates the broad range of engineering \r\nethics which combines whistle-blowing
column173:
and a fundamental 
consideration of the role of engineering in society.

When considering ethical engineering in Star Wars
column174: a new range of questions \r\nemerge which
column176:
we look forward to continuing to 
debate.  Was Luke Skywalker’s initial success only possible due to an 
ethical engineer? What is the balance of moral responsibility between the 
engineers and the force users? Does the final outcome of the battle between 
the light and dark sides depend upon engineering?  This is one role for 
science fiction in policy: to inspire questions
column178:
that further illuminate the technological challenges we face in 
society right now. Reflecting on the ethical engineering in Star Wars can 
serve as amusing but fruitful practice for ethical engineering in the real 
world.

------

https://twitter.com/scifipolicy

Footnotes:

[1] This is part of Hollywood’s habit of labeling as ‘science’ the most 
exciting parts of engineering. As Mark Watney said in The Martian while 
talking about many repair activities that were clearly engineering in 
nature: “I’m gonna have to science the shit out of this!” Do
such fictional representations affect the career choices of students
column180: when \r\nall the cool aspects of engineering are made to seem like science \r\nactivities? For more details on how engineering is different from science

column183:
Krennic kills seemingly all of the six or so engineers who worked for 
Galen. Apparently the engineers are all disposable whereas the ‘scientist’ 
in charge is not! That the engineers were both few in number and all very 
old
column184: white men seems deliberate.\r\n\r\n[2] (12/21/16 Edit: this footnote was accidentally left out
column185: thanks to RT \r\nfor noting error in comments.)\u00a0The Jedi and the Rebellion\u2019s use of \r\ntechnology is different from the Sith\u2019s. They use technology
column186: having their \r\nown fighter and cruisers that can fight with Star Destroyers
column187: but they \r\nnever attempt to make a singular weapon. In the prequels
column189:
as they don’t need to constrain their number due to a 
lack of trust. There are hints of a sort of craft knowledge amongst the 
rebellion: Han Solo’s relationship with the Millenium Falcon is one of 
craft and informal learning – one might suspect he’d enjoy the book Zen and 
the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance?  

[3] The clone wars are an interesting contrast here: did the creation of 
the clone army (and eventual stormtroopers) reflect a type of technological 
fix as well? In some ways
column191: but it\u2019s of a very different nature \r\nthan the Death Star. That was an example of a very distributed military
column192: \r\nwhich could exert a person-to-person style of military control across the \r\ngalaxy. The use of cloning technology is not necessary
column193: and perhaps Episode \r\nVII\u2019s use of non-clone but brainwashed stormtroopers is a return to that. \r\nThe Death Star
column195:
was a very singular and monolithic device that 
could destroy planets. Why did the Emperor decide to build the Death Star 
instead of building endless numbers of clones such that he would simply 
overrun all resistance?"
